titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Dore Ashton Papers, 1849, 1931-2010 in the Archives of American Art AAA.ashtdore
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Valerie Vanden Bossche
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing of this collection was provided the Smithsonian Institution Collections Care and Preservation Fund

note.p: This finding aid was created from a MARC collection-level record. 208698

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-09-17T15:52-0400

did.abstract: The papers of Dore Ashton measure 12.8 linear feet and date from 1931-2010, with one letter in the Joseph Cornell subject file dating from 1849. The records document Dore Ashton's career as an art critic, historian and educator, with particular depth for the period of 1952 through 1990. The collection contains a small amount of biographical material, over 4.5 linear feet of correspondence, writings, subject files, printed materials, artwork, and reference photographs of artworks.
did.langmaterial: Most of the collection is in English; some correspondence and printed materials are in French, Spanish, Italian, German, Norwegian, and possibly Latvian.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 7 series.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Ashton married artist Adja Yunkers (1900-1983) in 1953, and they had two daughters Alexandra (known as Sasha) and Marina. In 1985 she married writer Matti Megged (1923-2003).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Dore Ashton papers were donated to the Archives of American Art by Dore Ashton May 27, 1982, May 8, 1997, and June 2, 2011.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Dore Ashton papers, 1849, 1931-2010. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was partially processed by Jean Fitzgerald in 1997. The collection was minimally processed and a finding aid created by Valerie Vanden Bossche in 2013 with funding provided by the Smithsonian Institution Collections Care and Preservation Fund.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Among the holdings of the Archives is an oral history interview with Dore Ashton conducted November 21, 2010 by George W. Sampson, for the Archives of American Art's Elizabeth Murray Oral History of Women in the Visual Arts Project.
Dore Ashton papers are also located at Emory University Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Dore Ashton measure 12.8 linear feet and date from 1931-2010, with one letter in the Joseph Cornell subject file dating from 1849. The records document Dore Ashton's career as an art critic, historian and educator, with particular depth for the period of 1952 through 1990. The collection contains a small amount of biographical material, over 4.5 linear feet of correspondence, writings, subject files, printed materials, artwork, and reference photographs of artworks. The bulk of the collection consists of correspondence with many artists, writers and others, including Pat Adams, James Adley, Rudolf Arnheim, Jake Berthot, Dennis Congdon, George Herbert, Remo Guidieri, Barbara Howes, Fred Licht, Joan Punyet Miro, Carl Fredrik Reutersward, and Hedda Sterne, among others. Smaller amounts of letters are from Joseph Albers, Edward Albee, Richard Avedon, Richard Diebenkorn, David Driskell, Alberto Gicometti, Philip Guston, Lillian Hellman, Alger Hiss, Bernard Malamud, Joan Miro, Robert Motherwell, Lewis Mumford, Claes Oldenburg, Oliver Sachs, and Vassilis Vassilikos.

Writings consist of transcripts of miscellaneous articles or those written for various publications. Research files include reference or research materials for books, exhibitions, individuals and various topics. Individuals and topics include Jacopo Luis Borges, Allan Kaprow, Richard Lindner, Seong Moy, Jean Tinguely, Mark Tobey, Jack Tworkov, Adja Yunkers; and Dadaism, poetry and symbolism.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Dore Ashton records are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by type of material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Included in series 1 are Mather Award citation materials, typed introduction of Ashton by Frances Osborn Robb at TCU Honors Week Convocation 1978, scattered financial documents, miscellaneous notes and a folder of family documents and photographs. Additional family correspondence can be found in Series 2.2 alphabetical.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged in two subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains mixed business and personal correspondence from artists, family, friends, admirers, writers, publishers, museums, and galleries; many with enclosures including small artworks, exhibition announcements, poetry, and photographs and writings by others. There is a small amount of correspondence from Ashton to others. The largest amounts of correspondence are with Pat Adams, James Adley, Rudolf Arnheim, Jake Berthot, Dennis Congdon, George Herbert, Remo Guidieri, Barbara Howes, Fred Licht, Joan Punyet Miro, Carl Fredrik Reutersward, and Hedda Sterne, among others. A small amount of correspondence (one to six letters) is from Joseph Albers, Edward Albee, Richard Avedon, Richard Diebenkorn, David Driskell, Alberto Gicometti, Philip Guston, Lillian Hellman, Alger Hiss, Bernard Malamud, Joan Miro, Robert Motherwell, Lewis Mumford, Claes Oldenburg, Oliver Sachs, and Vassilis Vassilikos. Types of correspondence include holiday cards and postcards, as well as letters. Some letters and envelopes are illustrated. Correspondence is in English, Spanish, French, Italian, German and Norwegian. Additional correspondence may be found in Series 1 biographical materials and Series 4 subject files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by surname initial or full surname of person sent to

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Miscellaneous typescripts are arranged chronologically, followed by typescripts for specific publications arranged alphabetically by title of publication

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 3 contains miscellaneous typescripts for unidentified articles, and typescripts of articles and reviews for various publications including Arts and Architecture and the St. Louis Post-Dispatch.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by the broad topics of books, exhibitions, individuals and miscellaneous topics, then alphabetically by specific name or title

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Research files include materials on Ashton's books, on exhibitions, individuals, and miscellaneous topics. Included are clippings, artworks, photographic material, booklets, brochures, correspondence, and notes. Topics include Angry Art, civil rights, Czech, Polish, and religious art, film, Dadaism, poetry, print-making, and symbolism. Among individuals are Jacopo Luis Borges, Allan Kaprow, Richard Lindner, Seong Moy, Jean Tinguely, Mark Tobey, Jack Tworkov, and Adja Yunkers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by type of material, chronologically thereafter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed materials collected by Ashton include brochures and booklets, clippings, exhibition announcements and catalogs, galley proofs, press releases and programs. Topics include Dubuffet, Avedon, Ippolito, the New York School, collecting, Italian art, Jackson Pollock, sculpture, book reviews, and lectures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artwork includes various designs of a face and symbols on nine scraps of waxy paper; a Christmas card possibly designed by Adja Yunkers; 4.25x5.75 print signed Lichtenstein 1949; pencil or charcoal on paper design, dated Jan 23.52 marked "for Dore," illegible signature; collage print on paper entitled "Dore on the Beach," signed Adja Yunkers, with envelop from the Edna Hibel Gallery in New York.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by artist's surname, followed by subjects

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 7 contains black and white photocopy prints and a few prints and postcards, acquired by Ashton for reference, and representing mostly 19th and 20th century American and European artists. Most are labeled and of a single work of art, some show artworks in exhibition spaces.
